title: Cricket legend Dennis Lillee’s shock resignation from the WACA | The
text:
CRICKET legend Dennis Lillee’s shock resignation as president of the WA Cricket Association because he could “no longer stand by and watch what is happening”.
Lillee resigned on Tuesday night.
He spoke to Nine News Perth, but would not go into specifics.
“I couldn’t stand by and watch what is happening at the WACA,” he said.
“I do not wish to be a part of it any longer.”
Earlier on Wednesday, WACA chief executive Christina Matthews denied a personal falling out between her and Lillee was the reason for the sudden resignation.
Matthews said Lillee’s resignation on Tuesday night was “a bolt out of the blue’’ and he had not informed her of the reasons for his decision.
“We got on fine,’’ Matthews said.
“We’ve never had any stand-up barneys or not sort of talk to each other or anything like that.
“There’s always difference of opinions on how you do things, but other than that it’s fine.’’
Matthews said she was surprised at Lillee’s decision.
“I was surprised, as was everybody, this morning,’’ she said.
“There had been some discussion around the traps that he wouldn’t see out his full term, but we had no indication that he would be stepping down today.
“There’s nothing in the note he’s sent to us about why and I really think it’s probably up to him to explain why that would be.
“He’s been thinking about it for a while and he’s certainly been talking about it for three years and as far as I’m aware, it was going to happen after the AGM. So it did come as a bolt out of the blue last night.’’
Matthews was confident Lillee would remain a part of the WACA family.
“I expect Dennis to retain his place as an icon of the game and to attend games as he wishes to and to be a guest of ours at all our important events,’’ she said.
Lillee’s resignation is effective immediately.
It comes just two days before the release of a report on how much cricket should be moved from the WACA Ground to Perth’s new stadium at Burswood, across the other side of the Swan River.
The viability of the WACA Ground remains unclear, with the bulk of domestic and international limited-overs fixtures considered a chance to move to the new venue.
No other major Australian sport uses the WACA Ground.
The WACA’s future has been up in the air since their $500 million project to build high-rise apartments and a business precinct around the ground collapsed in 2013.
That failed bid ended up costing the WACA around $7 million.
Lillee’s resignation ends more than a decade at the helm of West Australian cricket.
Chairman Sam Gannon, who also started in his role in 2004, announced last month he would not seek re-election.
Gannon said Lillee’s resignation came “as a surprise”.
“However, I was previously aware that he was contemplating resigning from the Board prior to the end of his elected term,” Gannon said.
“I also reviewed my position after 11 years on the Board and thought it was an appropriate time to step aside and, accordingly, have not offered myself for re-election at this month’s AGM.
“The Board will seek to get some clarification from Dennis on his specific concerns and we will continue to work openly with our Members, staff and the media in regards to all appropriate information, as has been the WACA’s deliberate approach throughout my time as Chairman.”
Lillee said the failed redevelopment of the ground wasn’t a complete waste of time and money.
“The work has not been wasted, as the WACA has achieved planning approval for residential units and commercial space along with a significant increase in its land value,” Lillee said in the WACA’s financial report last year.
Lillee is one of Australian cricket’s most iconic figures.
The 66-year-old terrorised batsmen in the 1970s and ‘80s, capturing 355 wickets in a career spanning 70 Tests.
More recently, he played a key role in mentoring Australian pace ace Mitchell Johnson.
